comments.comment: <denchmark-link:https://github.com/LaurentBerger>@LaurentBerger</denchmark-link> I am actually not of the opinion that this is a bug, since asking for a region of interest of 0 pixels is just wrong ... the code works from the moment you provide at least 1 pixel... This is just how you should address the function. What you could do is add a check into the Mat ( Rect() ) creation that avoids this.

No I'm not agree. In my post (<denchmark-link:http://answers.opencv.org/question/68393/exception-using-umat/>http://answers.opencv.org/question/68393/exception-using-umat/</denchmark-link> ) I have test beahavior for Mat with opencl or not and UMat with or without opencl. This exception occurs only when Opencl is on and rect is empty using UMat <denchmark-code> rect not empty | rect empty Mat Opencl off no exception no exception UMat opencl off no exception no exception mat opencl on no exception no exception Umat opencl on no exception exception </denchmark-code>
Sorry for multiple message

IMHO, OpenCV (and other many libraries/frameworks/tools/etc) should detect when user want to shoot yourself in the leg. In this case it is empty ROI. So my suggestion is to add exceptions for all cases of empty ROI to show that something is going wrong and application developer should take a look on code.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/StevenPuttemans>@StevenPuttemans</denchmark-link> I'm agree asking a empty region is wrong. But I think like <denchmark-link:https://github.com/alalek>@alalek</denchmark-link> opencv should take care of parameters validity (not like my own program who send empty rect to UMat)
